summary:
I really should have more to say about this after many years of waiting it out to get one, but the simple truth is that the Magic Keyboard with Touch ID is just a great keyboard.  I probably should have caved years ago to purchase one. 
Don‚Äôt get me wrong; there were things that I quite liked about the Keychron K3 Ultra-Slim keyboard that I used to use ‚Äî namely, its fun, light-up colors, slick design, and trendy mechanical keys...
title: The Magic Keyboard with Touch ID Rules

summary:
Recently I‚Äôve been thinking about how everything that happens in the terminal
is some combination of:

Your operating system‚Äôs job
Your shell‚Äôs job
Your terminal emulator‚Äôs job
The job of whatever program you happen to be running (like top or vim or cat)

The first three (your operating system, shell, and terminal emulator) are all kind of
known quantities ‚Äì if you‚Äôre using bash in GNOME Terminal on Linux, you can
more or less reason about how how all of those things interact, and some of
their behaviour is standardized by POSIX. 
But the fourth one (‚Äúwhatever program you happen to be running‚Äù) feels like it
could do ANYTHING.  How are you supposed to know how a program is going to
behave...
title: "Rules" that terminal programs follow

summary:
A thought occurred to me last night as I had a brief conversation with Veronique on Bluesky last night.  She posted a quick thought about a TV show, Archive 81:
 

twenty min into watching archive 81 and i‚Äôm properly hooked
December 11, 2024 at 8:00 PM


My first thought was to reply and ask about the show - which I did - and we had a quick back-and-forth about it where she explained the brief premise.  I said that sounded interesting, and then when I looked into it further I discovered it was a podcast - we both found that interesting...
title: Conversations
